title-group.article-title: Railway axle failures and durability validation

author-notes.corresp: Gerhard Fischer, Menzelweg 6, Darmstadt 64291, Germany. Email: g.u.g.fischer@t-online.de

abstract.p: In this paper the influence of the approach taken to the design of train axles is considered and the shortcomings of the currently used procedures for fatigue strength validation are discussed. The procedure proposed in existing standards assumes a fatigue endurance limit, that is not realistically applicable to actual service conditions, and they do not take into account the real stresses encountered in actual service. The problems generated by such an approach are discussed using examples of actual failures of passenger train axles in Germany. A practice-related procedure for the service strength validation is proposed. This procedure includes service-related stress spectra and the fatigue strength of axles. To validate an axle design the time-varying stresses in individual critical areas of the axle, represented by their stress spectra, must be taken into account. The allowable stress levels in individual axle areas depend both on the fatigue strength and on the spectrum of operational stresses.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Recent evaluations of the causes of axle failures during service have shown that the so-called ‘endurance limit design’ approach adopted to date does not fully consider the conditions experienced in actual operational use.1–6

In the present European Standards used for the design of axles (EN 13,103 and 13,104), the maximum design stresses are calculated using specific load factors for traversing curves. The allowable stresses are based on the fatigue strength at 107 cycles. Neither of these standards satisfies the requirements concerning the required service life of axles. For an axle of an ICE train with a wheel diameter of 0.9 m and a travelled distance of 500,000 km per year a total of 484,000 axle revolutions or cycles are generated each day of usage; therefore, 107 cycles are achieved in about 21 days of operation. This high number of cycles leads to a continuous decrease of the fatigue strength.

Furthermore, the operational loads of trains at increased speeds or with an adaptive chassis response to track features (e.g. tilting technique) exceed the values assumed in the European Standards. If the service stresses are higher than the fatigue strength, initial cracks are generated which propagate, if not detected in time, and can cause the total fracture of the axle. This was the case in Germany on the high-speed trains ICE 3, ICE T (high-speed tilting train), ICE TD (high-speed tilting train with diesel engines), IC (tilting trains VT 611 and 612) and local trains (S and underground trains). The impact of these failures on the operation of trains and high costs for control of the problem or replacement of the axles with new and stronger axles, generated costs of several billions of Euros.
It should be noted that this problem is not solely confined to passenger trains: the freight train accident in Viareggio, Italy, must be regarded as being a result of an inadequate axle design.

sec.title: Factors that influence the structural durability of railway axles
sec.p:
The critical areas for the occurrence of fatigue in railway axles are at the press-fits (e.g. the wheel seat, the brake disc seat, the bearing seat, the labyrinth seal seat and the drive pinion seat for driven axles) as well as the axle fillet radii (Figure 1). Figure 1.
Critical areas for fatigue effects on a railway axle.

The factors, which play a decisive role in determining the level of structural durability are the service stress, which is a result of external loads, and the fatigue strength, which is determined by material properties, design, manufacturing technology and environmental factors.

From service measurements4,6–8 it is known that the service stresses have a time–varying characteristic (Figure 2) which is a result of the varying force levels on the rolling wheelset during service. The wheel and axle rotations create a stress cycle that is a function of the in-service conditions such as driving along straight track, driving round a curve or when crossing points, and has an amplitude-modulated characteristic. Figure 2.
Operational measurements of wheelset loads (Q-vertical load; Y-lateral load) and stresses on axle (SA) and wheel (SW).

Extreme wheelset forces, such as those that arise when running over points, produce stress peaks, which can occur numerous times over the course of a long service life. The service stresses can be described as a cumulative frequency distribution (stress spectrum) using counting methods; the usually used method for rotating components is the level crossing counting method.

The measured service stresses must be extrapolated to obtain the value for the total utilization duration, leading to a representative stress spectrum (Figure 3) from which the maximum value Sa* the distribution Sa = f(N) and the total number of cycles Ntot can be determined. Figure 3.
Spectrum of service stresses and fatigue strength depending on stress variation.

In addition to the service stresses the fatigue strength has a decisive influence on the structural durability. The fatigue strength determined under constant amplitude stresses (Woehler curve in Figure 3) is described by the slope k and the statistically proven scatter band Ts and TN. The knee point of this curve, usually occurring between 106 and 107 cycles, is called the endurance limit, Se. It is generally assumed that for steel materials at stress levels lower than this endurance limit Se no fatigue damage occurs and thus an unlimited life is to be expected.

The results of recent investigations concerning the fatigue life of components under service loading conditions and practical experience does not confirm this assumption. The main reason for this is that in service most components have stress time histories with variable stresses and a very high number of cycles and they are influenced by complex environmental conditions (corrosion, fretting, etc.) so the fatigue strength is continuously decreasing (very high cycle fatigue).
Therefore the Woehler curve is presented for fatigue life prediction as a curve with two slopes, k1 up to the knee point and k2 for the cycles after the knee point.

Influenced by developments in the aircraft and car industries, for which a lightweight as well as a ‘safe life’ design is of paramount importance, at the end of the third decade of 20th century, Gassner introduced an approach9 which took into account the variable nature of actual operational loading. The fatigue life under variable service stresses is presented as the Gassner curve, which is an analogue of the Woehler curve, and is described by the slope k* and scatter band, and is presented in Figure 3. The Gassner curve represents the relation between the durability life Ntot and the spectrum maximum value Sa* for a specific stress spectrum distribution Sa = f(N). For the comparative validation of the fatigue damage under variable and constant amplitude stresses a so-called ‘equivalent damage stress’ Sa,eq is used (Figure 3); Sa,eq is a constant amplitude stress which at Nt cycles generates the same fatigue damage as the specific stress spectrum. This usage-related service life evaluation technique (called structural durability validation) includes both the components fatigue strength as well as the service stresses including their scatter. The parameters of this procedure (service stress spectrum (design spectrum) and the corresponding fatigue life (Gassner curve)) must be determined by measurements and testing but could be estimated also by calculation in the design phase.
The fatigue strength of axles Se depends on material properties, local stress conditions at individual axle areas and on the manufacturing technology.

The increased demands that need to be met by axles on modern trains has resulted in high-strength materials being introduced; however, it should be noted that an increase in static material strength does not lead to a proportional increase in the fatigue strength.4–10 In addition, the higher sensitivity of the high-strength materials to notches, contact fatigue, material microstructure, surface conditions and corrosion has not been adequately considered during the process of determining the allowable stresses for the axles.

If the value of Se is related to the ultimate material strength Rm for axles with a diameter of about 200 mm and stress concentration at fillet radii Kt ≤ 1.5, approximately the following values are valid: Se ≈ (0.21–0.25)Rm for the axle’s free surface and Se ≈ (0.12–0.16)Rm for press-fits, the lower values are related to the materials with higher Rm values. As an example, the fatigue properties of an axle press-fit connection at the wheel seat for different materials is presented in Figure 4.4,8 Figure 4.
Woehler curves for wheel seat areas of different axles and materials under rotating bending, diameter of axles up to 190 mm.

Due to fretting fatigue constant amplitude tests show a large scatter and no fatigue strength limit (endurance limit). It was found by tests that at around 107 cycles the scatter between survival probabilities PS = 90% and PS = 10% for fatigue strength is Ts = 1 : 1.6 and for fatigue life TN = 1: 10. The investigations indicated that in the case of fretting fatigue a significant reduction of the fatigue strength occurred when the number of cycles exceeded 107.8–11

The test results shown in Figure 4 indicate that only a relatively small improvement of the fatigue strength can be achieved through utilization of a higher strength material in the press-fit assuming a similar diameter relationship. A greater improvement of the fatigue strength of axles, manufactured from high-strength materials, is found by increasing the diameter ratio ds/dg of the axle4–8,10 as shown in Figure 4. Which area of the axle is most critical, depends on the design of the axle. Roughly for values of ds/dg ≤ 1.16, usual press-fit conditions without surface treatment and typical stress concentration of the free axle surface Kt ≤ 1.3, the most critical area is the press-fit, which is also indicated by failures in service.

In addition to the choices of material and design approach other important factors in determining the fatigue life are the manufacturing technology and surface treatment. Thus, to increase the fatigue strength of press-fits different coatings and a combination of press-fit and bonding are used. Other methods of surface treatment such as induction hardening and rolling can also be used rather than choosing a high-strength material.5,8,9,11

sec.title: Durability validation based on the endurance limit
sec.p: For the case of durability validation based on an endurance limit, as presented in European Standards EN 13,103 and 13,104, the calculated highest service stress for moving around curves should be lower than the allowable (permissible) fatigue strength Sa,all corresponding to Se at 107 test cycles with original axles and specific security coefficients given in the standards, which depend on material, axle area (wheel seat, brake seat, fillet radius, etc.) and design (solid or hollow).

Evaluating the fatigue strength, an axle will not satisfy the requirements if the safety factor SF = Sa,all/Sa,calculated < 1. Alternatively, in the case that the safety factor is SF ≥ 1 the axle will achieve an infinite life! Consequently, a small change in the calculated stress or in the allowable stress will decide whether or not an axle is properly designed. Physically it is not possible that an axle, which is not sufficiently dimensioned, can achieve an infinite life merely by a small decrease in the stress or a small increase of fatigue strength at 107 cycles.
It must not be forgotten that a wheelset usually undergoes 107 cycles in about a month of operation.

sec.title: Structural durability validation
sec.p: Structural durability validation based on service stresses is the state-of-the-art in both the aircraft and road vehicle industries. The structural durability validation is carried out on the basis of the design spectrum resulting from operational use. This procedure is also mandatory to ensure correct design of wheelset axles and includes following steps:
Step 1: Design calculations based on data (and assumptions) on the loads and fatigue strength.
Step 2: Fatigue strength validation by tests.
Step 3: Determination of the operational loads by measurements.
Step 4: Final validation of the structural durability based on the service stresses and the verified fatigue strength.

The parameters of this procedure (service stress spectrum (design spectrum) and the corresponding fatigue life (Gassner curve)) are schematically presented in Figure 5. The design spectrum used for fatigue durability validation is defined by its maximum value Sa,D*, the distribution Sa = f(N) and the total number of cycles Ntot. Apart from the large total number of cycles in the giga-cycle range (Ntot > 109), the stress spectra of railway axles have a typical spectrum shape for rotating components, so that the most damage appears in areas with a large number of cycles. These spectra can be depicted as amplitudes and constitute the basis for making a service life estimation and for validation tests. They are also an indispensable prerequisite for defining the equivalent damage service stress values. The design life LD for trains is usually 30 years thus for regional trains that travel about 100,000 km per year this results in a total lifetime travel distance of about 3,000,000 km and for the long distance high-speed trains ICE, that approximately travel 500,000 km per year, to a lifetime distance of 15,000,000 km, corresponding to Ntot = 109 cycles. Figure 5.
Parameters for a reliable fatigue validation (schematic).
The relation between the durability life L and the stress S or between axle diameter d and the life is given by following equations.
Relation between life and stress (1)Lx=LD(Sa,D*/Sa,s*)k*

Relation between dimensions and life (2)dD=dx(LD/Lx)1/nk* where LD corresponds to the required service life (design life) to be achieved while experiencing a stress Sa,D* (which should correspond to a bearable stress Sa,b,99%), Lx is the life for the service stress spectrum with stress Sa,s*, k* is the exponent (slope) of the fatigue life curve (k* ≈ 6–8 for train axles depending on stress gradient, stress state and surface conditions in the critical area) and n is the exponent of stress dependence from dimensions (n = 3 for axles).
The necessary stress reduction of the stress Sa,s* or the increase of the axle diameter dx can be determined from the achieved life in service Lx and the required design life LD.

Based on the presented relation a 10% higher stress in the bearable stress leads, for a typical life exponent for axles of k* = 6, to a decrease of life by a factor of two. The higher 10% stress could be generated by a 3% reduction in axle diameter.

The durability life of axles can be estimated using the data of the constant amplitude tests (Woehler curves), with the modified damage accumulation hypothesis of Miner, according to the state-of-the-art in the structural durability evaluation. Based on investigations and experience for the damage calculation in the giga-cycle fatigue range (N > 107 cycles), the slope for Woehler curves k2 = 2k1 − 2 (Figure 3) should be taken for press-fits (to take the effect of fretting fatigue into account), and a value k2 = 2k1 − 1 for other axle areas. A value of D = 0.5 should be used as the total permissible damage for the fatigue life estimation.

If a comparison between the fatigue damage of a stress spectrum and the fatigue strength resulting under constant amplitude load is required, the so-called equivalent damage stress Sa,eq can be determined with the help of a comparative damage calculation. The equivalent damage stress, shown in Figure 3, is a constant amplitude stress for a given number of cycles Nt which leads to same damage level D as the stress spectrum with Sa,D*, stress distribution Sa = f(N) and Ntot cycles. Usually, the equivalent damage stress is determined for Nt = 107 cycles so as to be able to compare it with the fatigue strength of axles, which in most cases is determined in laboratory tests under rotating bending with constant amplitudes.

The evaluation of the durability life is based on the following equation (3)Lx=LD(Se/Sa,eq)* where Se corresponds to the fatigue strength under constant amplitude at 107 cycles with a probability of survival Ps ≥ 99% and Sa,eq to a constant amplitude stress generated at 107 cycles which creates an equivalent damage to the damage of the stress spectrum.

As the criterion for the fatigue life a so- called technical crack is used, which allows the axle to be used without the possibility of the creation of a total fracture. Using this procedure a premature axle failure is avoided; this is a result of the required high probability of survival and the corresponding low failure rate, as shown schematically on Figure 5. For properly designed components the crack propagation rate on an axle is relatively low. If the design and dimensions do not satisfy the requirements, failures will occur before the required durability life is achieved and both the failure rate and the crack propagation rate become larger. Shorter inspection intervals become necessary in order to detect such a crack before a total axle fracture occurs. The portion of the axle fatigue life between an initial and detectable crack and the critical crack, at which the axle fracture is generated, is important in terms of safety. It should also serve as a basis to determine the inspection intervals to detect the cracks before they achieve a critical size.

To determine the maximum permissible crack length, the possible extreme load in operational usage generated by a seldom occurring special event, has to be taken into account. It must be assured that an axle with a certain crack length but in use does not fail under such a load. For service-like tests with original wheelsets8 it was found that the type of crack propagation after the initial cracks were generated depended on the stress level in the cracked area and the stress distribution along the crack propagating section. This is the reason why the life fraction between a detectable crack and the critical crack size, differs for the case of fractures on press-fits and on a free axle surface.

Because the fatigue life of properly designed axles at crack initiation is a multiple of the crack propagation life, it is imperative that the axles are properly designed for the required service usage. This usage-related design procedure is a ‘fit for purpose’ design and includes both a safe life and damage tolerance philosophy11,12 and is from the economic perspective the best solution since it allows reliable, cost-saving inspections.
Examples of failed axles on high-speed trains operated in Germany will be discussed in the next section in order to validate the points made about structural durability.

sec.title: Structural durability validation of modern train axles
sec.p: Despite the described developments in the study of fatigue behaviour the endurance limit approach is still the primary route taken for the design and subsequent validation of the structural durability of train components.

This is the case for axles of modern trains, with design validation being based on the endurance limit value and the assumption of an unlimited fatigue life, as employed in ‘Design method – European Standards EN 13,103 and 13,104’ as discussed in Traupe et al.10 The result of this approach is that in recent years many fatigue failures have occurred on trains in service.3–8,13 The results of forensic analyses on representative failures on modern German trains will be discussed in this paper.

The first example concerns the derailment of an ICE TD (VT 605) train that occurred in December 2002. Analyses of the fracture, material and service loading (measurement of axle loads and stresses in service) were carried out. It was determined that the fracture started in the contact zone of the wheel seat to the axle and propagated to the area with stress concentration at the fillet radius, see position 1 in Figure 6. The measured maximum service stress was about 30% higher than the stress calculated using the standard EN 13,103.4,6 Figure 6.
Position of the axle fractures of individual train axles; position 1: fracture on ICE TD (VT 605), position 2: cracks on IC (VT 612) and position 3: fracture on ICE 3.

The second example concerns the existence of cracks on the Intercity tilting trains VT 612 and VT 611 detected in July 2004 using ultrasonic control. The fatigue cracks started in all cases in the fillet radius of the stress-relieving groove beneath the wheel seat (position 2 in Figure 6). The service measurements, carried out after the cracks were found, lead to the conclusion that the service stresses were about 23% higher than those calculated using the standard EN 13,103.

The third example concerns the derailment of the high-speed train ICE 3, no. 518, which derailed at low speed leaving the main station of Köln (Figure 7) on 9 July 2008, due to the fracture of a powered axle, position 3 in Figure 6. The measured maximum stresses for this type of train were found to be about 20% higher than those calculated using standards EN 13,103 and EN 13,104.10

The crack started at the fillet radius in the area of the peak stress due to the stress concentration. It was decided that an ultrasonic testing of all axles must be carried out every 30,000 km, which means about every month, causing very high costs and problems for effective scheduling. Eventually, in October 2009, it was decided to completely replace the axles. In July 2008 after the fracture occurred on the axle of the ICE 3 train, cracks were detected on axles of the high-speed tilting train ICE T, which were manufactured from the material 30NiCrMo6 (Rm = 1000 MPa). Figure 7.

In all cases the cracks and fractures were generated by fatigue due to the variable service loads. The structural durability evaluations of these axles are summarized in Figures 8 to 10. Figure 8.

sec.title: Fatigue evaluation of the IC-VT 612 train axle
sec.p: The results of the analysis of the IC-VT 612 train axle are summarized in Figure 8. The service stress spectrum was derived from measurements based on a yearly usage of 200,000 km and a service life of 30 years, corresponding to a total lifetime travel distance of 6,000,000 km.

The calculation of the stresses using EN 13,103 resulted in a nominal stress value in the highly stressed section of the fillet radius of Sa,n = 177 MPa and a local structural stress of Sa,calculated = 230 MPa at a stress concentration factor of Kt = 1.3 which was determined from a finite element modelling analysis.

The measured stress amplitude of the local bending stress in service was Sa,s* = 284 MPa, which is roughly 23% higher than the calculated stress. During the service measurements a superimposed torsion was also measured, so that the resulting equivalent stress, to be used for the fatigue evaluation is Sa,s* = 295 MPa. Due to the shape of the spectrum and the 2.2 × 109 cycles, the equivalent damage stress in relation to the maximum service stress is Sa,eq = 0.77 × Sa,s* = 0.77 × 295 MPa = 227 MPa. The bending fatigue strength at 107 cycles, determined by tests on small specimens and axles using a procedure proposed in the EN 13,103/04 standard vary between Se = 171 MPa and 131 MPa.10

The expected durability life, checked using equation (3) is between Lx = 6 × 106 (171/227)6 = 1,100,000 km in the case of Se = 171 MPa and Lx = 6 × 106 (131/227)6 = 222,000 km for the case Se = 131 MPa. It follows that a value of the fatigue strength of the axles of Se = 131 MPa is a more reliable value as confirmed by the in-service failure of axles.

sec.title: Fatigue evaluation of the ICE TD train axle
sec.p: The results of the analysis of the ICE TD axle are summarized in Figure 9. The service stress spectrum was derived from measurements on the actual track with the train being driven in both directions in order to mimic normal operation and be able to take into account the different loadings on the guiding and non-guiding axles of the bogie.

Assuming a yearly usage of 400,000 km the design spectrum for 30 years in service, corresponding to a total travel distance of 12,000,000 km was obtained as shown in Figure 9. The maximum nominal stress amplitude in service reached a value of Sa,s* = 122 MPa, which is roughly 30% higher than the calculated stress of Sa,n = 95 MPa.

Due to the shape of the spectrum, the number of about 4 × 109 cycles and taking into account the influence of contact fatigue (fretting corrosion) in the critical area of the wheel seat, the equivalent stress corresponds to the maximum service stress (Sa,eq = 1.032Sa,s* ).

Comparing the damage equivalent stress Sa,eq = 1.032Sa,s*, Sa,s* = 126 MPa with the data presented in Figure 4 for axles made from 34CrNiMo6 (a fatigue strength at 107 cycles of Se = 97 MPa with probability of survival Ps = 90% and 80 MPa with Ps = 99%, based on scatter Ts = 1 : 1.4) it is obvious that the required service life cannot be achieved.

Estimation of the fatigue life using equation (3) with a slope of the fatigue life curve of k* = 7 and LD = 12,000,000 km, results in a value of Lx = 499,000 km which is equivalent to 1.25 years of service which approximately corresponds to the achieved durability life.

sec.title: Fatigue evaluation of the ICE 3 train axle
sec.p: The results of the analyses of the ICE 3 axles are summarized in Figure 10. The fatigue validation is based on a design load of 17 t and a required life of 15,000,000 km, corresponding to 30 years of service. The powered axles are manufactured, as in the case of ICE TD axles, from 34CrNiMo6 and the non-powered axles from 25CrMo4 (EA4T).

The results of measurements performed by Traupe et al.10 are used in the validation of the durability life. Based on these measurements and the calculations of the stress in individual sections of axles, using standard EN 13,103 (non-powered axle) and EN 13,104 (powered axle), it was found that the maximum service stresses are about 20% higher than the equivalent calculated value: Sa,s*≈1.2Scalculated

The design stress spectrum for a 30 year service life at 500,000 km per year derived from service measurements is reproduced in generalized form in Figure 10. Based on damage calculations for the given stress spectra the equivalent stress related to the maximum service stress in the critical area of the wheel seat is Sa,eq = 0.962Sa,s* and for the free surface at the fillet radius Sa,eq = 0.844Sa,s*. This means that for the axles of ICE 3, the required fatigue strength at 107 cycles is higher than that calculated using the EN 13,103 and 13,104 standards stress; for the area of wheel seats the results are Se = Sa,eq = 0.962 × 1.2Sa,calculated = 1.154 Sa,calculated and for the fillet radius Se = Sa,eq = 0.844 × 1.2Sa,calculated = 1.013Sa,calculated.

For example, in the free axle surface at the fillet radius, based on calculated nominal stress Sa,calculated =145 MPa for the powered axle the required fatigue strength is Se = 147 MPa. Taking into account a fatigue notch factor of Kf ≈ 1.2 in this area the fatigue strength is lower than the required value. Applying equation (3) the estimated fatigue life is about 5,400,000 km. The achieved service life of only 3,000,000 km is with a great probability influenced by a higher service stress than that used in the fatigue validation (possibly caused by a non-spherical wheel) or lower fatigue strength than assumed due to a material failure. An analysis of material in the zone near the crack initiation revealed non-metallic inclusions up to a length of 0.9 mm and it was suggested that such inclusions could influence the axle fracture.14

To increase the fatigue life from Lx = 3,000,000 km to the required LD = 15,000,000 km a redesign of the axle in the case of unchanged fatigue strength is necessary as follows dB=dx×(LD/Lx)1/n×k*=dx×51/3×6=dx×1.09

This means that an increase of 9% in the existing axle diameter (d = 179 mm at wheel seat and 160 mm between the wheel and drive gear seats) is necessary (and would be sufficient) to achieve the required service life (d = 195 mm at the wheel seat and 174 mm between wheel and gear seats).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The proposed procedure for fatigue evaluation differs significantly from the approach based on endurance limit design for which a small change in either the calculated stress or the fatigue strength leads from a non-permissible to an infinite life design and fulfills the usage-related requirements.4,8,11 Even though the accuracy of the fatigue life estimation can be influenced by the level of allowable damage D as well as the values of k1 and k2 of the Woehler curve, it is a more accurate approach than validation based on an assumed, but practically non-existing endurance limit and specific material-dependent security coefficients. The procedure takes the real mechanical and physical conditions which govern the fatigue damage of axles in service into account.

The problems observed to occur with the axles of German trains are the result of following effects.
A relatively low safety factor, which does not take sufficient account of the decrease of the fatigue strength endurance limit for cycles higher than 107; for example, a safety factor of 1.66 is used for powered axles based on European Standards (low alloy steel A4T), which is significantly lower if compared to a value of 2.58 used for high-speed trains in Japan.11
A 20 to 30% higher maximum service stress than the value calculated based on the load assumption in European Standards EN 13,103 and 13,104.

A practice-related procedure for a reliable design validation of railway axles, which takes into account European Standards, is proposed and described in chapter 3.3 of Fischer and Grubisic.4 The fatigue fractures of train axles that occurred in service, could have been avoided if the salient influencing parameters had been taken into consideration during the design phase. Apart from the considerable potential danger involved, the costs for a reliable durability validation are only a small fraction of the costs otherwise incurred later by recall actions and replacement by modified axles. A summary of the axle failures in service including a juridical treatment related to individual responsibility is presented in Kuhlwetter.13

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: An analysis of observed cracks on modern trains has resulted in the conclusion that a structural endurance limit does not exist and thus the reliable approach used to validate the structural durability must be based on a finite durability life that takes into account the structural fatigue properties under real usage conditions. It is highly important that this knowledge, as the state of the art, is applied for structural durability validation and also included in taught courses as well as in specific standards.

The following statements summarize the state of the art in this area.
An optimal as well as reliable design of wheelset axles must take into account the operational stress spectra (or axle loads) and the fatigue strength of axles. An appropriate procedure must ensure that these decisive factors are adequately considered.
The estimation of the expected fatigue life must include statistical aspects of the scatter of the components fatigue strength.
In the design stage, the fatigue strength validation and resulting dimensioning should be based on the appropriate loading and fatigue strength data, including specific safety factors for the required design life. The allowable (permissible) stress, represented by Sa,eq for N = 107 cycles depends on the fatigue strength in an individual axle area as well as on the design spectrum for the required service life.
For the inspection of axles, it is necessary to improve the numerical procedures used to estimate the crack propagation and verify them both by experimental investigations and by practical experience.
A reliable approval of axle durability, especially in the case of new materials, manufacturing technology and train types, should include an experimental validation in the existing durability test facilities taking into account the service stress spectra as is current practice in the car and aircraft industries.
